newsitem.title: USA: FCOJ futures slump as weather concerns ease.
newsitem.headline: FCOJ futures slump as weather concerns ease.

text.p: FCOJ futures slumped as concerns about cold weather damaging the Florida citrus belt eased, traders said, but one forecaster warned against a "freeze scare" in the northern part of the region over the coming weekend.
"We still see cold weather coming in but there is no reported call for a freeze, and in view of that we saw a setback in the market," FCOJ specialist Celeste Georgakis of Dean Witter Reynolds said.
"The fundamentals continue to be bearish and that puts a lid on prices," Georgakis added.
March orange juice settled 2.60 cents weaker at 79.75 cents per pound, traded 82.00 to 79.20 cents. Volume was estimated at 3,500 lots compared to Tuesday's official 3,743 lots.
Weather forecaster Jon Davis of Smith Barney said the cold airmass moving down the country from Canada needed to be watched as it reached Florida's citrus belt.

"In the very least, it is a freeze scare. Based on guidance this morning it looks like the coldest morning with this Arctic surge will be Sunday morning," Davis said. Lows across the citrus belt will be 28-35 (Farenheit) range.

"Some minor fruit damage is possible in the northern portion of the belt," Davis said, adding that about half the crop had already been harvested. The southern part of the belt was safe from any damage.
